The degree of a polynomial f=
sum a_i X^i in R[X], denoted by deg f, is defined as the maximum i such that a_i 
eq 0. The degree is assigned -
infty for the zero polynomial.
A polynomial $f$ in a ring $R[X]$ is irreducible if it cannot be factored into the product of two non-constant polynomials in $R[X]$.
Does the concept of a/an Degree of a Polynomial need to be defined for a definition of a/an Irreducible Polynomial to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To determine if a polynomial is irreducible, one must assess whether it can be factored into the product of two non-constant polynomials. The concept of a non-constant polynomial inherently involves the degree of the polynomial. A non-constant polynomial is one whose degree is at least 1. Therefore, understanding and defining the degree of a polynomial is crucial to identifying whether a polynomial is non-constant. Without the concept of the degree of a polynomial, it would be challenging to define what constitutes a non-constant polynomial and, consequently, to apply the definition of an irreducible polynomial. Thus, the concept of the degree of a polynomial is necessary for the definition of an irreducible polynomial to be meaningful and applicable.
